overview_of_class: The general objectives of this course are to make students familiar with central ideas of statistics as they are applied in social research, to enable understanding of statistical methods commonly used in social science research articles, and to enable students to use these methods to perform an analysis of social data.
name: Analysis and Interpretation of Social Data
title: WCAS SOCIOL 303-0-20 Analysis and Interpretation of Social Data

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The general objectives of this course are to make students familiar with central ideas of statistics as they are applied in social research, to enable understanding of statistical methods commonly used in social science research articles, and to enable students to use these methods to perform an analysis of social data.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
During preregistration this course is only open to Sociology Majors & Minors.

This course is open to all undergraduates during regular registration, starting February 22.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: At the end of this course students should be able to: use graphs, tables, and measures of central tendency and spread to summarize data; compute and interpret correlations and regressions for pairs of variables; explain random sampling using probability concepts; explain what a sampling distribution is and give a rudimentary explanation of its role in inferential statistics; test hypotheses about means, proportions, and regression coefficients; calculate and explain confidence intervals; understand how relations among variables may change when other variables are statistically controlled; explain basic regression output; and use statistical software to perform basic statistical analysis.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
This is a tentative booklist. Please confirm all books before purchasing.
George Bohrnstedt and David Knoke. "Statistics for Social Data Analysis." (4th Edition). F.E. Peacock Publishers. 2002.
